Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Virginia State University (VSU) will implement a comprehensive project which will result in an increase in the numbers of STEM graduates from an average of 70 to over 105 per year by the end of the five-year project. Project activities will attract and prepare high school students by giving them an opportunity to explore, learn and experience several STEM disciplines. Course and curriculum enhancement, and advance teaching technology especially for the gatekeeper courses, will improve student skills and retention in STEM. Students and faculty will have opportunities to enhance their knowledge and research skills through specially designed learning activities. The project will also support the smooth transition of STEM undergraduates into highly competitive graduate school programs.

Intellectual Merit: This program will provide access to science and technology and opportunities by addressing some existing barriers for participation in all of the science arenas. Strategies will focus on (1) learning with technology, not about technology; (2) emphasizing content and pedagogy not just hardware; (3) providing professional development in technology, and (4) promoting interdisciplinary scientific research. The project will provide opportunities for undergraduate students to become engaged in the most challenging and exciting interdisciplinary scientific research projects.

Broader Impact: The project will foster close interactions between faculty and students to encourage the academic potential of the minority students in the STEM fields at VSU. Students will have the opportunity to interact with students from Ivy League institutions in order to encourage their participation in the graduate programs at these institutions. The project will also expose students to modern teaching techniques and learning experience in gatekeeper courses. The project is also intended to improve the quality of science and mathematics education at VSU enhancing the institutional capability moving the University toward a higher institutional status.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the inception of the T-STEM project, 411 high-school students have participated in the Pre-College Program (grades 9-12) and, to date, 178 of those students have gone on to attend VSU. That number is expected to increase because some of these students are still in high school. So far, 19 of these students have graduated from VSU and four of them are currently attending graduate schools. 144 students attended the GRE Preparation classes. More than 1,500 students participated in the VSU Annual Undergraduate Research Conference that is sponsored by the VSU HBCU-UP project. Our students attended at least two off-campus conferences every year.

 

As a direct result of the VSU HBCU-UP project, the following external funds were obtained:

$4.2M from the NIH under RIMI Program

$400k from NASA for two proposals

$700k from Department of Education under MSEIP for three proposals

$50k from DuPont in support of the HBCU-UP

$1M from NSF under Educational Research

$250k from NSF under MRI

$85k from NSF under BRIGE program

$342,795 from NSF under HBCU-UP Broadening Participation grant

$10k from Microsoft

$23k from Opportunity Inc for support of the HBCU-UP summer programs

 

The average number of graduates in VSU STEM degree programs has increased from 70 to101 per year within the last five years.

The average GPA of the STEM students has increased from 2.6 to 2.9 within the last 5 years.

The Graduate Bridge phase of the VSU HBCU-UP which started in 2007 has increased the number of B.S. graduates who pursue graduate education. Since 2007, there has been a big jump in the number of students who enter graduate schools within one year of their graduation. The average number of VSU STEM graduates who entered a graduate STEM program at any university within one year of their graduation has increased from an average of 2 per year (between 2001-2006) to 7 per year (between 2007-2009). In addition, since 2007, some of the graduates entered graduate programs at Penn State (2), Georgia Tech, Norfolk State, Stevens Institute of Technology, Rowan (2), Old Dominion, U. of Connecticut, Howard, and Georgetown.

As a direct result of the NSF T-STEM program, the size of VSU’s STEM Honor enrollment has increased from 61 students in 2004-2005 to 107 students today. This will have a positive impact on the future graduation rate and graduate school attendance of VSU’s STEM students.


Last Modified: 12/08/2011
Modified by: Ali A Ansari
